One of the coolest aspects about interviewing VR developers at this stage of the industry is that everyone involved is in it for the passion. No one is in it for a quick buck. It‚Äôs all love. And I am so grateful that we have the chance to capture these recording on our podcast üíú

@Disco_VR 10m+ units sold. The party isn‚Äôt empty anymore. It‚Äôs time to sell for the real price. They‚Äôve captured the market. I understand the decision. To me, it means the goal set with the previous price tags were accomplished and it‚Äôs time to adjust accordingly.

@Disco_VR Meh it was heavily subsidized before. There‚Äôs an apology we use at the gym I work. When the party is empty, you need to get the show going by any means. Let people in free, whatever. Once the party is going and people see all the fun, and they want in‚Ä¶ well‚Ä¶

1. You don‚Äôt need a computer to play #VR.

@JayHadHope @bozoid @NathieVR But yeah that massive stock drop was just them going back to where they were prior to covid. World shut down, more people used Facebook. People resumed life, they used Facebook less. https://t.co/hEpDtz3YH1

@JayHadHope @bozoid @NathieVR Its their stock returning to where it was prior to covid. So much of their stock is based on daily active users. Which, during lockdown, skyrocketed. When the world returned to normal, their daily active users dropped and they reported it during forecasted earning, stock dropped
@SurvivormanVR So exciting see the progress on this over the months. Great work and it‚Äôs really cool seeing this get closer and closer
